trial_identification.studytitle: A trial of screening strategies for Cervical cancer prevention in Vanuatu
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A comparative study of three screening strategies for determining cervical cancer risk amongst 30-50 year old Vanuatu women
trial_identification.secondaryid: CICR-0602 The University of Queensland Centre for Immunology and Cancer Research

conditions.healthcondition: Cervical cancer screening in healthy women

interventions.interventions: Screening interventions - each done to each trial subject on one occasion only. 1) Visual Inspection of the cervix after application o f Acetic Acid (VIA) and after application of Lugol's Iodine (VILI), 2) Cervical Cytology on a Papanicolau smear sample , 3) Human Papillomavirus testing (Performed on the Papanicolau smear sample) Cervical Biopsy is the reference standard - taken from all subjects with any abnormality on any test, and on 10% of subjects with all tests normal.
interventions.comparator: The comparator is a Cervical Biopsy

primaryOutcome.outcome: detection of Biopsy proven cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia (CIN) 2/3
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Within one month of presentation for screening

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Relative efficacy of screening tests as assessed by their positive predicitve value, and negative predictive value, for biopsy proven CIN 2/3
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: On completion of data collection (12 months after study completion)

fundingsource.fundingaddress: c/o Dr Margaret McAdam Adelaide St Brisbane Queensland 4000

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To assess the relative effectiveness of three possible means of early detection of cervical cancer risk in a population of healthy women in vanuatu.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: The University of Queensland Human Ethics Experimentation Committee
ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: The University of Queensland St Lucia Queensland 4072

contact.name: Ian Frazer
